Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: SafeLi: Graphene monoxide anodes for extreme batteries
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project arises from bringing new materials to market for making improved rechargeable lithium ion batteries needed by the high-tech economy, medicine, and the military (batteries are the second largest military consumable). In today's world, everything, including medical devices (e.g., wireless implants and sensors), has an app; using apps requires batteries. This project will produce "Safer Energy for the Wireless World"; the resulting improved batteries will incorporate novel, lighter, and safer (no overheating) anode materials that will charge faster and store more energy than current versions. The new anode materials are estimated upon success to yield sales of $1B during the first 10 years from selling the materials to battery manufacturers to incorporate, initially, as composites in lithium ion battery anodes, and, later, as the entire active anode. Broader societal impacts include greater safety because the batteries do not overheat; lighter, more portable devices with longer battery life and faster recharging time; reduced need for backup batteries; and diverse STEM workforce development though applied research and entrepreneurship training.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop safer, more powerful ways to charge electronic devices by translating fundamental research from university to industry. The opportunity arises from an NSF-supported discovery of the first solid form of carbon monoxide known, a two-dimensional crystal structure: graphene monoxide (GmO). GmO and its first proposed application for anodes in lithium ion batteries are patented. Knowledge gaps to be addressed include identifying tailored materials for optimizing batteries for electronics, using theoretical and experimental approaches to identify the maximum energy storage capacity for lithium batteries, and determining the energy and power densities and safety properties under normal and extreme operating conditions. The technology must be demonstrated in 200-mAh pouch batteries, the first milestone needed for battery manufacturers to consider adopting the innovation through licensing or sales. The second milestone is to scale up materials to produce large quantities. The overall goal is to commercialize the GmO material into an active anode or additive material for extreme batteries. In sum, the project will yield prototype batteries made from the new materials, optimize properties for specific partner applications, simulate interactions between GmO and Li, and identify pathways for scaleup of materials production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to create model lithium ion batteries for consumer electronics applications using anode formulations containing graphene monoxide-based materials (GmO), and to test the batteries against control cells under normal operating and fast-charging conditions at room-temperature and low-temperatures. Additional goals were to determine the mechanism(s) of lithium uptake/release and transport in GmO, to determine the theoretical capacity of GmO, and to develop strategies for industrial-scale production of GmO-based materials that best fit customer needs for consumer electronics.

We achieved a minimum viable product 200-mAh battery using composite graphene monoxide material as a 10% additive to silicon-graphite active anode battery formulations for high energy density applications. Battery testing demonstrated: i) significantly higher capacity under room-temperature fast-charging conditions vs graphite control cells; ii) the ability to function at -20°C where a graphite control cell failed to operate; and iii) significantly better cycling performance at 0°C vs silicon-graphite control cell. These technical milestones indicate that SafeLi’s advanced materials can be developed for commercialization in next generation Lithium Ion Batteries for consumer electronics applications. A provisional patent was filed to protect these findings.

The density functional theory work done under this Phase I funding resulted in the preparation of one complete manuscript, significant portions of a second manuscript, and possible future manuscripts building from the results of this funding. The first manuscript will be submitted for publication in summer 2020, where the theoretical specific capacity of GmO was determined and sites for Li storage in the GmO structure were determined. The results presented in the manuscripts address energetics of Li transport parallel and perpendicular to the 2D GmO structure and allow for speculation on mechanisms underlying observed performance of batteries made with composites of GmO. Ongoing calculations and efforts will further the theoretical understanding of uptake/release and transport of Li in GmO in progressively sophisticated calculations involving bilayers and multilayers that have been initiated under this funding. Calculations have also been initiated to understand data collected from the anodes of batteries that have been made from different GmO-based materials, in lithiated vs delithiated states of charge, and for first-cycle vs high-cycle batteries.

Additionally, materials were produced in our lab in small-batch quantities to test synthesis parameters and to learn how variations to lab-based procedures and processes could impact material synthesis at industrial scales. Design of experiment studies were conducted with post-doctoral associate participation to shed insight into patterns in existing data of material properties vs synthesis parameters to quantify the impact of synthesis control. Building on results of prior work (DOE Phase I and consultations with SafeLi’s business advisory board members), specific aspects of the lab-based synthesis were identified and methods for how each synthesis aspect can be approached independently during scale-up efforts were determined. Beyond protocols to scale up lab-based procedures, other potential roadblocks to commercialization are starting to be addressed under other funding sources while building on outcomes of this funding.


Last Modified: 05/20/2020
Modified by: Marvin A Schofield
